out why Trophy Hunting is good for animals,

First muntjack the other day and I'm going

and Dom is also hoping to get a chance at

I know there are a lot of animals down here

He's had a bit of a dry spell leading up this

124.52.text:
Normally when I am struggling with the outings

it hasn't worked for the last five days as

Stalking Chinese involves making the most

early morning light they can be tougher than

See the one now, that ones good - okay - that

It's just as she steps forward but she drops

186.81.text:
Yes, that's good, yes nice - the pressure

Young female. This years youngster - that

means she would have been born in May. A good

This is totally new but really nice. It is

terrain. As I said, it is always nice to crawl

Even at distance the shot looks like it has

Yes, sometimes if your Deer runs on, obviously

I think even Stevie Wonder could have followed

Dom has shot one CWD before so knows the score,

It can't hurt can it.The lucky coin worked.

Two fields over Paul is happy there's another

Yes, I am happy with that. You are happy,

That's a nice entry, that's bang on. Oh yes,

I was aiming so that's okay, thank you Paul.

get a Man with a cough this bad anywhere close

322.42.text:
That's double. Yes, you can go home with your

Paul has had a busy week catering for a load

There is a new US injured soldier rehab programme

takes combat veterans out after American wildlife,

Did you fall-off out hunting and was the moment

2015. Email photos to hunting@countryside-alliance.org

And finally, we don't have film, we don't

Roy Lupton towing his Argocat on the M25,

453.53.text:
for the Dartford Tunnel, thanks very much

457.90.text:
You are now up-to-date with Fieldsport Channel
News, Stalking the stories, fishing for facts.

466.48.text:
Now the fox hunting season has officially
opened except, of course, without the foxes.

473.75.text:
I've been down to Dorset, to meet a couple
of people who are turning it into big business.

479.64.text:
The Queen's Arms in Corton Denham, a sleepy
village in Dorset. Home today to horse. Power.

486.56.text:
I'm a motor head. I'm going to take this Astin
Martin to the coast and test it out.

499.53.text:
OK that's an American who is not hunting.
His wife and two friend, however, are hunting.

504.46.text:
We're fine with that. Not jealous at all.
They should be jealous of us I think!

510.30.text:
This happy group is togged up and ready to
go out for one of the finest days the English

514.45.text:
countryside has to offer. So let's start with
the togging is that normal for Americans?

519.72.text:
It is and when I first started hunting I thought,
boy there is way too much emphasis on the

523.68.text:
clothing but when you learn why you where
this it's a respect to the landowners who

527.90.text:
allow us to hunt on their property, well then,
that makes sense.

531.82.text:
I hunt with Casanova hunt, which is near Warrington,
Virginia and we are with Carolina Hunt and

534.00.text:
also with Casanova Hunt. We are very fortunate.
We have some really nice hunts near us.

545.25.text:
There you have it. They take it as seriously
as we do. Right let's fast forward to the

549.41.text:
meet. Here is the hunting tour operator who
brought the Americans here.

553.57.text:
That is true, we're not really in the right
car for following today. We had a job parking

557.90.text:
it. This is a lovely bit of classic Blackmore
vale country, you've got quite open, lovely

564.07.text:
hedges. And today, Mike Felton is our Master.
He looks after that central part of Blackmore

570.01.text:
Vale. This Vale country is the famous stuff.
You know, good dairy country, lovely manicured

574.97.text:
hedges if hounds run there is a lot of fun
to be had down here. It's quite nice that

579.35.text:
not everybody who hunts wants to hunt every
day and it is really nice that we can include

583.11.text:
spouses , friends, children, if they want
to come and soak up some of the atmosphere

587.85.text:
here without getting on a horse. You see people
going to such lengths. You see horses beautifully

592.74.text:
turned out. Coats are clean, Buttons are shining.
It's quite special. I'd like to see three

598.22.text:
very muddy coats from my mounted followers,
but with big smiles and I would like to see

604.32.text:
not so muddy coat for Mike here as we step
out of the car still looking like James Bond.

609.84.text:
Hello, I've already got a muddy coat. Four
muddy coats!

614.47.text:
The Americans mount up. They are no slouches
when it comes to funny English tack.

619.12.text:
We have a standing martingale, we don't normally
have these rings like this but it is pretty

624.37.text:
much the same setup as we have in the States.
We're used to this. Like a ride at home. And

632.69.text:
Hunting people, being hunting people, are
delighted to see other hunting people..

637.12.text:
I'll take them round my house tomorrow evening
for a quick drink and show them some of my

642.20.text:
pictures and something else to fill in their
programme. So long live Americans!

647.62.text: And there's a welcome from the MFH too.

648.62.text:
If I could just interrupt this drinks party
for a moment please, can I also just extend

654.14.text:
a welcome to our American visitors here today.
Very nice to see you. Welcome to the BV - I

663.86.text:
hope you don't get too closely acquainted
with our mud.

667.36.text:
So Mike and Ben are off with the Aston, the
others are on horses, and I hitch a ride with

671.56.text:
the quadbikes. As well as 60 people on horses,
there are forty on foot, in cars, on motorbikes

677.08.text:
and on quads. That's 100 people in a small
rural area keen enough to take a whole Monday

685.73.text:
Star of the field is Charlotte on Cracker.
Cracker is 35 years old. Charlotte is just

692.35.text:
We are trail hunting today, and the first
cover to draw is a patch of rough land by

697.03.text:
a brook. A roebuck gets up ware haunch as
hunting people say and it heads off into the

704.59.text:
It's a lot easier to keep up with the action
on a horse but it is a lot easier to film

708.82.text:
as a foot follower. The rest of the day I
spend with the folk in their various vehicles

713.37.text:
trying to intercept the hunt as it goes past.
One of them has invented a clever way to watch

718.64.text: proceedings from the comfort of his car.

721.87.text:
I was getting told off for getting up on the
roof and denting it in so I made this up to

729.40.text:
stop that and hey presto I came up with this
to keep within the law at the backend of the

736.70.text: Some of the followers have less good ideas

739.21.text: I always come hunting in these shoes.

741.85.text: I catch up with one of our Americans

745.38.text:
One of the foot followers is the farmer on
whose land we start.

749.26.text:
First meet on the farm since we've been here
in 11 years, having moved down from Oxfordshire,

753.63.text:
so it's nice to see everyone out today. Very
good. It's nice to see the older generation.

758.11.text:
Especially the older people following. It's
all part of the countryside and its nice to

763.05.text:
see them getting involved and some of the
young children here as well.

766.15.text:
At the end of the day, trails have been followed,
and the Americans have a couple of jumps to

770.74.text:
Lucky launched off and he was like smack on
the bank and he's like laid out and I'm like,

775.64.text:
sitting and I'm like okay, come on come on
and he's got up and he -

779.52.text:
did you hold your neck strap?
Yes I did.

781.21.text:
Yes he did.
He grabbed the neck strap. He kicked for him

781.69.text:
to go on up.
And I gave him is full head for him to go

786.33.text:
Looks like they are coming again. If you want
to enjoy traditional English foxhunting even

791.84.text:
if for the time being it's without the fox
visit BlackthornAndBrook.com

799.17.text:
Good to see Hunting alive, kicking and thriving
despite the worst that Tony Blair could do

803.52.text:
to it. Now it is a truth, universally acknowledged
that the bigger the animal you shoot the larger

809.78.text:
the headline you create in your local newspaper.
I have been abroad to find out why hunting

819.77.text:
There has been a lot of flapping in the media
recently about trophy hunting. Foreigners

827.31.text:
taking pot shots at Elephants and Rhinos.
Well, I haven't come to Africa to find out

832.03.text: more about it. I've come to Denmark.

834.88.text:
I'm at the Trophy Hunting Museum in fabulous
Valdemars Castle to meet Claus Olesen. He

840.42.text:
is going to show me Europe's largest collection
of big game trophies that's open to the public,

845.29.text:
and he runs nature courses here for schools,
too. He wants to explain to me why big game

852.40.text:
For example if you take Lions, they are a
good example. They pay for their own existance

861.25.text:
because when they take some of their Massi
people cows, they pay them. In Tanzania they

869.97.text:
have the worlds largest populations of wild
Lion due to the trophy hunt.

875.44.text: So supposing there was no hunting?

877.28.text:
They don't have the money. Kenya can be the
other example. They don't have any trophy

881.44.text:
hunting. There is no compensation paid so
the Massi, they poison the lions when they

887.38.text:
take one of their cows they put poison in
the body and when they come back there, there

891.78.text:
is no problem with lions any more as they
are dead.

895.72.text:
Claus points out that southern white rhino
numbers have increased to around 20,000 from

900.61.text:
a low of 2,000 in the 1980s thanks to the
money from big game hunting. What's knocking

905.25.text:
the numbers back today is poaching, not hunting.
Is that real rhino horn behind you, Claus?

910.81.text:
No! We don't dare to have the real Rhino horn
as the price is so enormously high. It would

917.44.text:
encourage burglars to come here and take it.
If that was real Rhino horn there how much

926.79.text:
One of the arguments against hunting is that
the people who do it must be weird to want

930.60.text: to knock over a big, beautiful animal.

932.99.text:
I go shooting as well, hunting and I don't
think I am sadistic or whatever your pointing

939.60.text:
at but I think I take part in nature. I am
living in it and living with it and I think

948.00.text:
it is the same with the trophy hunter.They
take part and every day some animals are going

954.03.text:
to die one way or another and if we can give
benefit to the local population whilst providing

964.27.text:
trophies for the trophy hunters I think it
is a good thing.

967.45.text:
It's not always about African animals. Claus
has this shaggy sheep story from Pakistan.

972.68.text:
The Markhurst is a very good example. In the
1960's there was only 30 left of this Kasmir

978.05.text:
Markhorn. Exactly the same story as with the
Rhino's. It eats the same food as the livestock

984.82.text:
did so they had to get some benefit from it.
There was no trophy hunting but there was

990.94.text:
a Danish guy and he said if you stop poaching
I will pay you 10,000 dollars next year. And

997.86.text:
in 1983 the Pakistan government thought now
the population is big enough we can allow

1002.31.text:
for one bull to be shot but nowadays there
are three populations of different Markcross

1008.77.text:
and there are fifteen let free for trophy
hunting every year which pays about 100 - 150,000

1016.72.text:
dollars each license and the money gets back
to the local areas where the villagers are

1023.76.text:
running the schools, their health care systems,
the benefit of the trophy hunt. So they think

1030.94.text:
it is very good to have this Macro because
they can get much more out of them.

1038.08.text: Have you got any records here?

1040.92.text:
Yes I have this one. This is a world record.
It is an East African Sitatunga.

1052.28.text:
Well, that's a new one on me. So, now for
some fun for you. How good are you at your

1059.44.text:
big game species? Here's a quiz. Rules are
simple: you get a few seconds of the animal,

1064.30.text:
then its name pops up on the screen. No prizes,
no pack drill, off you go.

1116.64.text:
That's it. For more about this museum, go
to BorgeHinschFonden.dk

1120.76.text:
Well I hope you got ten out of ten there Claus.
Now shooting is not just about accuracy of

1126.22.text:
identification, it's about accuracy of shot
placement. Here is Tim Pilbeam to show you

1130.10.text: how to stop your scope from becoming wobbly.

1134.96.text:
Most of us are pretty good at looking after
our shooting kit, otherwise it gets expensive

1148.89.text:
and or you start missing; to show how important
it is to keep everything locked down sporting

1154.85.text:
rifle contributor Tim Pilbeam is going to
see what happens to your zero when you loosen

1159.74.text:
the scope mounts on a rib fire and a full
bore rifle.

1165.96.text:
Ill be just loosening these mounts off. We
will just look at the change of point of impact.

1172.62.text:
We'll be shooting at 100 metres so we should
see a fair bit of change. It could be quite

1177.91.text:
tricky because this is a rimfire and there
is not much recall but I am rather hoping

1182.13.text:
that if I just loosen off the rear side, the
rear mount that we will be able to see a change

1187.76.text:
in the point of impact so the screw tension
is about 45 inch pounds. Let us drop it down

1192.12.text:
to 20 then with this loosened off we will
hopefully see some changes.

1200.39.text:
What has happened actually is, you can see
the point of impact has actually moved, probably

1204.82.text:
two inches up and an inch to the left. I didn't
think,in fact, it would move that much but

1210.66.text:
I backed it off by about 10-5 inch pound and
I moved the scope a wee bit and it has moved

1219.91.text:
it a good two inches so I am quite surprised
by that. So the most important thing is to

1224.45.text:
make sure all your mounts are kept pretty
tight.

1227.03.text:
The results show significant deviation. Next
up is the centre fire rifle with a lot more

1232.95.text:
It is the 270WSM. Quite a punchy rifle. It
is a light rifle as well so a lot of force

1240.18.text:
will be coming back at me and this is when
really good quality mounts come into it because

1245.99.text:
if they are not tight enough things will move,
my god they will do with this recall.

1252.07.text:
Okay, first shot, second shot, third shot
,so the rifle is more or less zeroed. I loosened

1264.56.text:
the mount from 60inch pounds to 30. Didn't
really make a huge difference. Then I loosened

1270.13.text:
the mounts down to 5inch pounds and immediately
we have a three inch rise impact. It demonstrates

1279.99.text:
it really well. I am really pleased about
that.

1282.05.text:
So, maybe its not breathing, trigger weight,
wind, temperature, incline or star sign - maybe

1287.31.text:
it is just a case of getting a grip on that
scope.

1291.37.text:
